title: Rotational dynamics - force and torque from pivot

content.question: A uniform bar is initially at rest on a horizontal surface when the two forces indicated in the top-view figure are exerted at the ends of the rod. The bar is free to rotate about a fixed a pivot at the bar’s center that anchors the center of the bar to the horizontal surface. Friction forces are negligible. As indicated by the arrows in the figure, <math alttext="F sub 1 is greater than F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. A student claims that at the instant shown in the figure the pivot is exerting a nonzero force on the bar and exerting a nonzero torque on the bar about the pivot. Is the student’s claim correct? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because the forces and torques are unbalanced. Therefore, the pivot must balance the forces and torques.
Yes, because the pivot will act to prevent the rotation and sliding of the bar.
No, because while the pivot does exert a nonzero force on the bar to balance the applied forces, the pivot exerts no torque because the force is applied at the axis of rotation.
No, because frictional forces are negligible, and therefore the bar slides freely on the pivot and the pivot exerts no force or torque on the bar.

content.answer: No, because while the pivot does exert a nonzero force on the bar to balance the applied forces, the pivot exerts no torque because the force is applied at the axis of rotation.
